turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Hey, just cancel that shit right now! You're hurt. You're hurt really fucking bad, but you ain't dying.

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: All this blood is scaring the shit outta me. I'm gonna die, I know it.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Oh excuse me, I didn't realize you had a degree in medicine. Are you a doctor? Are you a doctor? Answer me please, are you a doctor?

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: No, I'm not!

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Say-the-goddamn-words: You're gonna be okay!

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: I'm okay.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Correct.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Just hold on buddy boy. Hold on, and wait for Joe. I can't do anything for you, but when Joe gets here, which should be anytime now, he'll be able to help you. We're just gonna sit here, and wait for Joe. Who are we waiting for?

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: Joe.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Bet your sweet ass we are.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I ain't going anywhere. I'm right here. I'm not gonna leave ya.

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: Larry, I'm so scared, would you please hold me.

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: Look, I don't wanna be a fly in the ointment, but if help doesn't come soon, I gotta see a doctor. I don't give a fuck about jail, I just don't wanna die.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: You're not gonna fucking die, all right?

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: I wasn't born yesterday. I'm hurt, and I'm hurt bad.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: It's not good...

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: Hey, bless your heart for what you're trying to do. I was panicking for a moment, but I've got my senses back now. The situation is, I'm shot in the belly. And without medical attention, I'm gonna die.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I can' take you to a hospital.

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: Fuck jail! I don't give a shit about jail. But I can't die. You don't have to take me in. Just drive me up to the front, drop me on the sidewalk. I'll take care of myself. I won't tell them anything. I swear to fucking god, I won't tell 'em anything. Look in my eyes, look right in my eyes.  I-won't-tell-them-anything. You'll be safe.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Lie back down, and try to -

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: I'm going to die! I need a doctor! I'm begging you, take me to a doctor.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: Blonde went crazy. He slashed the cop's face, cut off his ear and was gonna burn him alive.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Uhuh, uhuh, what's I tell ya? That sick piece of shit was a stone cold psycho.

turns.speaker: MR. ORANGE
turns.text: You could've asked the cop, if you didn't just kill him. He talked about what he was going to do when he was slicing him up.

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: Have you guys been listening to K- BILLY's super sounds of the seventies weekend?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Yeah, it's fuckin' great isn't it?

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: Can you believe the songs they been playin'?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: No, I can't. You know what I heard the other day? "Heartbeat-It's Lovebeat," by little Tony DeFranco and the DeFranco Family. I haven't heard that since I was in fifth fuckin' grade.

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: When I was coming down here, I was playin' it. And "The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia" came on. Now I ain't heard that song since it was big, but when it was big, I heard it a million-trillion times. I'm listening to it this morning, and this was the first time I ever realized that the lady singing the song, was the one who killed Andy.

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: C'mon, throw in a buck.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Uh-uh. I don't tip.

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: Whaddaya mean you don't tip?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I don't believe in it.

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: You don't believe in tipping?

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: I don't even know a Jew who'd have the balls to say that. So let's get this straight. You never ever tip?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I don't tip because society says I gotta. I tip when somebody deserves a tip. When somebody really puts forth an effort, they deserve a little something extra. But this tipping automatically, that shit's for the birds. As far as I'm concerned, they're just doin' their job.

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: I'd go over twelve percent for that.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Look, I ordered coffee. Now we've been here a long fuckin' time, and she's only filled my cup three times. When I order coffee, I want it filled six times.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: These ladies aren't starvin' to death. They make minimum wage. When I worked for minimum wage, I wasn't lucky enough to have a job that society deemed tipworthy.

turns.speaker: NICE GUY EDDIE
turns.text: Ahh, now we're getting down to it. It's not just that he's a cheap bastard -

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Do you know what this is? It's the world's smallest violin, playing just for the waitresses.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: You don't have any idea what you're talking about. These people bust their ass. This is a hard job.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: So's working at McDonald's, but you don't feel the need to tip them. They're servin' ya food, you should tip em. But no, society says tip these guys over here, but not those guys over there. That's bullshit.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Waitressing is the number one occupation for female non-college graduates in this country. It's the one job basically any woman can get, and make a living on. The reason is because of tips.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Fuck all that.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Gun shot.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Oh that's just fucking great! Where's Brown?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Dead.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Goddamn, goddamn! How did he die?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: How the fuck do you think? The cops shot him.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Oh this is bad, this is so bad.  Is it bad?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: As opposed to good?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: This is so fucked up. Somebody fucked us big time.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: You really think we were set up?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: You even doubt it? I don't think we got set up, I know we got set up! I mean really, seriously, where did all those cops come from, huh? One minute they're not there, the next minute they're there. I didn't hear any sirens. The alarm went off, okay. Okay, when an alarm goes off, you got an average of four minutes response time. Unless a patrol car is cruising that street, at that particular moment, you got four minutes before they can realistically respond. In one minute there were seventeen blue boys out there. All loaded for bear, all knowing exactly what the fuck they were doing, and they were all just there! Remember that second wave that showed up in the cars? Those were the ones responding to the alarm. But those other motherfuckers were already there, they were waiting for us.  You haven't thought about this?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I haven't had a chance to think. First I was just trying to get the fuck outta there. And after we got away, I've just been dealin' with him.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Well, you better start thinking about it. Cause I, sure as fuck, am thinking about it. In fact, that's all I'm thinking about. I came this close to just driving off. Whoever set us up, knows about this place. There could've been cops sitting here waiting for me. For all we know, there's cops, driving fast, on their way here now.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Let's go in the other room...

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: What the fuck am I doing here? I felt funny about this job right off. As soon as I felt it I should said "No thank you", and walked. But I never fucking listen. Every time I ever got burned buying weed, I always knew the guy wasn't right. I just felt it. But I wanted to believe him. If he's not lyin' to me, and it really is Thai stick, then whoa baby. But it's never Thai stick. And I always said if I felt that way about a job, I'd walk. And I did, and I didn't, because of fuckin' money!

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: What's done is done, I need you cool. Are you cool?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I'm cool.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Splash some water on your face. Take a breather.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Want a smoke?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Okay, let's go through what happened. We're in the place, everything's going fine. Then the alarm gets tripped. I turn around and all these cops are outside. You're right, it was like, bam! I blink my eyes are they're there. Everybody starts going apeshit. Then Mr. Blonde starts shootin' all the -

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: That's not correct.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: What's wrong with it?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: The cops didn't show up after the alarm went off. They didn't show till after Mr. Blonde started shooting everyone.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: As soon as I heard the alarm, I saw the cops.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I'm telling ya, it wasn't that soon. They didn't let their presence be known until after Mr. Blonde went off. I'm not sayin' they weren't there, I'm sayin' they were there. But they didn't move in till Mr. Blonde became a madman. That's how I know we were set up. You can see that, can't you, Mr. White?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Look, enough of this "Mr White" shit -

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Don't tell me your name, I don't want to know! I sure as hell ain't gonna tell ya mine.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: You're right, this is bad.  How did you get out?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Shot my way out. Everybody was shooting, so I just blasted my way outta there.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Tagged a couple of cops. Did you kill anybody?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: A few cops.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: No real people?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Uh-uh, just cops.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Could you believe Mr. Blonde?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: That was one of the most insane fucking things I've ever seen. Why the fuck would Joe hire somebody like that?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I don't wanna kill anybody. But if I gotta get out that door, and you're standing in my way, one way of the other, you're gettin' outta my way.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: That's the way I look at it. A choice between doin' ten years, and takin' out some stupid motherfucker, ain't no choice at all. But I ain't no madman either. What the fuck was Joe thinkin'? You can't work with a guy like that. That motherfucker's unstable. What do you think? Do you think he panicked, or ya think he's just trigger-happy?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I think he's a sick fuckin' maniac! We're awful goddamn lucky he didn't tag us, when he shot up the place. I came this fucking close -  to taking his ass out myself. Everybody panics. When things get tense, everybody panics. Everybody. I don't care what your name is, you can't help it. It's human nature. But ya panic on the inside. Ya panic in your head. Ya give yourself a couple a seconds of panic, then you get a grip and deal with the situation. What you don't do, is shoot up the place and kill everybody.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: What you're supposed to do is act like a fuckin' professional. A psychopath is not a professional. You can't work with a psychopath, 'cause ya don't know what those sick assholes are gonna do next. I mean, Jesus Christ, how old do you think that black girl was? Twenty, maybe twenty-one?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Did ya see what happened to anybody else?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Me and Mr. Orange jumped in the car and Mr. Brown floored it. After that, I don't know what went down.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: At that point it became every man for himself. As far as Mr. Blonde or Mr. Blue are concerned, I ain't got the foggiest. Once I got out, I never looked back.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: What do I think? I think the cops caught them, or killed 'em.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Not even a chance they punched through? You found a hole.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Yeah, and that was a fucking miracle. But if they did get away, where the fuck are they?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: You don't think it's possible, one of them got a hold of the diamonds and pulled a -

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: How can you be so sure?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I got the diamonds.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I got 'em, all right?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Where? Are they out in the car?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: No, they're not in the car. No, I don't have them on me. Ya wanna go with me and get 'em? Yes, we can go right now. But first listen to what I'm telling you. We were fuckin' set up! Somebody is in league with the cops. We got a Judas in our midst. And I'm thinkin' we should have our fuckin' heads examined for waiting around here.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: That was the plan, we meet here.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Then where is everybody? I say the plan became null and void once we found out we got a rat in the house. We ain't got the slightest fuckin' idea what happened to Mr. Blonde or Mr. Blue. They could both be dead or arrested. They could be sweatin' 'em, down at the station house right now. Yeah they don't know the names, but they can sing about this place. I mean, that could be happening right now. As we speak, the cops could be in their cars, drivin' here this minute.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I swear to god I'm fuckin' jinxed.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Two jobs back, it was a four man job, we discovered one of the team was an undercover cop.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: No shit?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Thank god, we discovered in time. We hadda forget the whole fuckin' thing. Just walked away from it.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: So who's the rat this time? Mr. Blue? Mr. Blonde? Joe? It's Joe's show, he set this whole thing up. Maybe he set it up to set it up.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I don't buy it. Me and Joe go back a long time. I can tell ya straight up, Joe definitely didn't have anything to do with this bullshit.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Oh, you and Joe go back a long time. I known Joe since I was a kid. But me saying Joe definitely couldn't have done it is ridiculous. I can say I definitely didn't do it, cause I know what I did or didn't do. But I can't definitely say that about anybody else, 'cause I don't definitely know. For all I know, you're the rat.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: For all I know, you're the rat.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Now you're using your head. For all we know, he's the rat.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: That kid in there is dying from a fuckin' bullet that I saw him take. So don't be calling him a rat.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Look, asshole, I'm right! Somebody's a fuckin' rat. How many times do I hafta say it before it sinks in your skull?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I gotta take a squirt, where's the commode in this dungeon?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Go down the hall, turn left, up those stairs, then turn right.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: So, is he dead or what?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: He ain't dead.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: So what is it?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I think he's just passed out.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: He scared the fuckin' shit outta me. I thought he was dead fer sure.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: He will be dead fer sure, if we don't get him to a hospital.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: We can't take him to a hospital.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Without medical attention, this man won't live through the night. That bullet in his belly is my fault. Now while that might not mean jack shit to you, it means a helluva lot to me. And I'm not gonna just sit around and watch him die.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Well, first things first, staying here's goofy. We gotta book up.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: So what do you suggest, we go to a hotel? We got a guy who's shot in the belly, he can't walk, he bleeds like a stuck pig, and when he's awake, he screams in pain.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: You gotta idea, spit it out.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Joe could help him. If we can get in touch with Joe, Joe could get him to a doctor, Joe could get a doctor to come and see him.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Assuming we can trust Joe, how we gonna get in touch with him? He's supposed to be here, but he ain't, which is making me nervous about being here. Even if Joe is on the up and up, he's probably not gonna be that happy with us. Joe planned a robbery, but he's got a blood bath on his hands now. Dead cops, dead robbers, dead civilians... Jesus Christ! I tend to doubt he's gonna have a lot of sympathy for our plight. If I was him, I'd try and put as much distance between me and this mess an humanly possible.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Before you got here, Mr. Orange was askin' me to take him to a hospital. Now I don't like turning him over to the cops, but if we don't, he's dead. He begged me to do it. I told him to hold off till Joe got here.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Well Joe ain't gettin' here. We're on our own. Now, I don't know a goddamn body who can help him, so if you know somebody, call 'em.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I don't know anybody.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Well, I guess we drop him off at the hospital. Since he don't know nothin' about us, I say it's his decision.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Well, he knows a little about me.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: You didn't tell him your name, did ya?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I told him my first name, and where I'm from.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Why!

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: I told him where I was from a few days ago. It was just a casual conversation.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: And what was tellin him your name when you weren't supposed to?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: He asked.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: We had just gotten away from the cops. He just got shot. It was my fuckin' fault he got shot. He's a fuckin' bloody mess - he's screaming. I swear to god, I thought we was gonna die right then and there. I'm tryin' to comfort him, telling him not to worry, he's gonna be okay, I'm gonna take care of him. And he asked me what my name was. I mean, the man was dyin' in my arms. What the fuck was I supposed to tell him, "Sorry, I can't give out that information, it's against the rules. I don't trust you enough."? Maybe I shoulda, but I couldn't.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Oh, I don't doubt is was quite beautiful -

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Don't fuckin' patronize me.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: One question: Do they have a sheet on you, where you told him you're from?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Well that's that, then. I mean, I was worried about mug shot possibilities already. But now he knows:  what you look like,  what your first name is,  where you're from and  what your specialty is. They ain't gonna hafta show him a helluva lot of pictures for him to pick you out. That's it right, you didn't tell him anything else that could narrow down the selection?

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: If I have to tell you again to back off, me an you are gonna go round and round.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: We ain't taking him to a hospital.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: If we don't, he'll die.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: And I'm very sad about that. But some fellas are lucky, and some ain't.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: That fuckin did it!

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: You wanna shoot me, you little piece of shit? Take a shot!

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Fuck you, White! I didn't create this situation, I'm just dealin' with it. You're acting like a first- year fuckin' thief. I'm actin like a professional. They get him, they can get you, they get you, they get closer to me, and that can't happen. And you, you motherfucker, are looking at me like it's my fault. I didn't tell him my name. I didn't tell him where I was from. I didn't tell him what I knew better than to tell him. Fuck, fifteen minutes ago, you almost told me your name. You, buddy, are stuck in a situation you created. So if you wanna throw bad looks somewhere, throw 'em at a mirror.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: He got it in the belly. He's still alive, but won't be for long.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Enough! You better start talkin' to us, asshole, cause we got shit we need to talk about. We're already freaked out, we need you actin freaky like we need a fuckin' bag on our hip.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Is that supposed to be funny?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: We don't think this place is safe.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: This place just ain't secure anymore. We're leaving, and you should go with us.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Both of you two assholes knock it the fuck off and calm down!

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: So you wanna git bit, huh?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Cut the bullshit, we ain't on a fuckin' playground!  I don't believe this shit, both of you got ten years on me, and I'm the only one actin like a professional. You guys act like a bunch of fuckin' niggers. You ever work a job with a bunch of niggers? They're just like you two, always fightin', always sayin' they're gonna kill one another.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: You said yourself, you thought about takin' him out.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Then. That time has passed. Right now, Mr. Blonde is the only one I completely trust. He's too fuckin' homicidal to be workin' with the cops.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: You takin' his side?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Fuck sides! What we need is a little solidarity here. Somebody's stickin' a red hot poker up our asses and we gotta find out whose hand's on the handle. Now I know I'm no piece of shit...  And I'm pretty sure you're a good boy...  And I'm fuckin positive you're on the level. So let's figure out who's the bad guy.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I told ya he'd be pissed.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: What are you gonna do about him?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: He seems all right now, but he went crazy in the store.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: This is what he was doin'.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: ...Hey, I know what I'm talkin' about, black women ain't the same as white women.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: There's a slight difference.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Okay, Mr. Expert. If this is such a truism, how come every nigger I know treats his woman like a piece of shit?

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: I'll make you a bet that those same damn niggers who were showin' their ass in public, when their bitches get 'em home, they chill the fuck out.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Not these guys.

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Yeah, those guys too.

turns.speaker: MR. WHITE
turns.text: Who cares what your name is? Who cares if you're Mr. Pink, Mr. Purple, Mr. Pussy, Mr. Piss...

turns.speaker: MR. PINK
turns.text: Oh that's really easy for you to say, you're Mr. White. You gotta cool-sounding name. So tell me, Mr. White, if you think "Mr. Pink" is no big deal, you wanna trade?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Hello Graham -- Joe -- Mr. Gardner.

turns.speaker: GARDNER
turns.text: Graham's got something to tell you might interest you.

turns.speaker: GARDNER
turns.text: You should be. Maybe Lednov heard about that Sonora ranch of yours.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Maybe he did.

turns.speaker: GARDNER
turns.text: We're going to look for him. Want to come along?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I've got eleven horses to get over the mountains before snow catches me and covers the feed.

turns.speaker: GARDNER
turns.text: And that's more important than finding Lednov?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Like you said, maybe he knows where my ranch is. If he does, he'll be waiting on the porch.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Who shot who?

turns.speaker: GARDNER
turns.text: Nobody. The light was bad.

turns.speaker: GARDNER
turns.text: What's she doin' runnin' around the country at night.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I wouldn't know. Did you ask her?

turns.speaker: GARDNER
turns.text: All I can get out of her is she don't care about livin'.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Look of things, she doesn't.

turns.speaker: GARDNER
turns.text: Yeah. Keep a closer eye on her --  And him. Shootin' going on, we'll never find Lednov.

turns.speaker: MRS. WYATT
turns.text: You don't know how good it is to see you.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Maybe you won't feel that way after I tell you what I stopped in for.

turns.speaker: MRS. WYATT
turns.text: Tell them to come on in.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: But I'm going to have to leave 'em here. They're --- well they're not the sort of people you're used to.

turns.speaker: MRS. WYATT
turns.text: It doesn't matter who they are.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: And one of 'em is sick.

turns.speaker: MRS. WYATT
turns.text: Why didn't you say so. Go right out and get her. Ed. build the fire up.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Anybody hurt?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No. We came down the hill a little fast and...  ...the wheel broke.  Can you fix it for us?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What's the matter with her?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Too much excitement. How about the surrey. Can you fix it?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: This must have been in the family a long time.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: It was a gift from the citizens of Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And this is Helen Carter.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm Clay Phillips.  My brother Steve.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: As far as -- Sonora?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Just about.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: They won't be riding in the wagon.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Did you ever try taking a bunch of horses over Sonora Pass? It's quite a job.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You can't leave us here.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Course I can't. I'll give you a lift to the first ranch.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What good is it going to do us to go to some ranch?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You can stay here if you like.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We have to get to Sonora. There are jobs waiting for us there. We'll pay you for your trouble.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm not running a stage line, ma'am, and I can't take a chance on losing the horses.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Our kind of women?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You'll have to drive -- except down hill.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What's the matter with her?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Too much excitement. Or maybe it's just the heat. How about the surrey. Can you fix it?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And this is Helen Carter.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm Clay Phillips.  My brother Steve.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: So am I.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's a nice place owned by an old couple named Wyatt.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thanks. And isn't there something we can do about supper -- or making the beds?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Steve and me, we use a saddle for a pillow and roll up in a tarp.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But you eat, don't you?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Mostly, we open a can of beans and boil some coffee.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Where do you keep the can opener?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: In the grub box.  Toward morning the dew gets kind of heavy so maybe you better fix up a bed under the wagon. Spread some bunch grass under the tarp and the ground won't be so hard.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Of course it'll work. You can get another girl to fill out the act.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: And look at it this way. How about Jim -- it puts him in a sort of tough spot.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: If you were in his shoes would you take one of us home?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm not in his shoes, so leave me out of it.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Steve maybe you better get some wood for the fire.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Would you, Mr. Phillips?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Go on, there's a good boy.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: There's a nice boy.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: That why you always took him on the other side of the street?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Like sticking his nose into other people's business.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Get back to the horses. They're straggling.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He's learning his letters.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Yeah. While the horses wander all over the country.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Learnin' to read has nothing to do with the right or the wrong side of the street.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Are the horses stragglin' or aren't they?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: They're stragglin'.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: His letters will keep.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: But the nearest shelter's the Wyatt ranch and that's maybe five hours away.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Can we get a doctor at that ranch?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No, Ma'am, we can't. We can get a roof and a fire and maybe Mrs. Wyatt knows something about taking care of sick people.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: So that was why she tried to run away.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Didn't you know she had a father and mother out here?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I didn't know anything about her except she wanted a job because some man had left her stranded. I couldn't leave her in the street. Let's go.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Hold on.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: We can't stay here!

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's a long walk back to Aspen.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Coffee?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, thanks.  I hope we won't be a burden to them.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I hope so, too.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm sorry, but that's how it's got to be.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I suppose it is.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: And it's not only because the trip's a tough one --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You don't have to explain. Did I tell you how grateful I am for what you've done?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I couldn't leave you sitting by the road.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You could have treated us like they did in Aspen. No. You wouldn't do a thing like that -- it isn't in you to be mean or cruel.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I hope you get everything you want out of life --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You've earned it -- the horse ranch on the Toulomoe -- the girl in the spotted gingham.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: The who?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You should know. She's in your dream.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Ever since you've looked after Steve you've had the dream -- a ranch on the river -- good grass, good water, barn corral and house --- that part you've shared with Steve. The girl in gingham you plan sneakin' in when he isn't looking.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Go on. Tell me more about her.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: She wears this gingham dress -- cooks popovers -- makes jam in season -- makes her own soap from pig fat and wood ashes and has cheeks the color of red apples.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'll make the soap myself.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: But the rest is right.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Will she be dark or fair?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Blonde as a new mop. And beautiful as the girl on a feed store calendar.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: He knows his alphabet.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's fine.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Are we leaving?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's too light yet.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Better go on back and get some more sleep. You'll need it later on.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You're not going out to look for them?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No, I'm not. All I want 'em to do is keep ahead of us -- a long way ahead. So I'm riding up the line aways to pick us out a new trail.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Don't you trust me?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Not on this trail, I don't. I've been over it before. Anyway, you ought to be pretty sleepy. Why don't you climb in back.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why did you change your mind about bringing us along?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Why do you think?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't know. I thought I did. Now I'm not sure. I thought it had something to do with me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Oh, it did. It had a great deal to do with you.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You know so much about me -- figure it out.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: So that's it --  You think I was making fun of your girl in gingham.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: You wouldn't do a thing like that, would you?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Yes. But -- that was the other night. Now -- I don't think I would.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You should have. I don't like leaving things unfinished.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Maybe it's better that way.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: You don't mean that Clay.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Tell me, darling.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: What does a man usually tell a girl?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: What did you expect? Speeches I don't mean?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I don't expect anything. A minute ago I hadn't cuite waked up.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm awake now. Go on. Say what you want to say. I'll listen.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: If it's pretty speeches you want, you won't be hearing them. Even when I mean 'em, they don't come easy.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Save 'em for the girl in gingham. Just tell me I'm not good enough for you. Go on. Say a woman like me can't change.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: All right -- it's said!

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Then let's get started. The sooner I get to Sonora, the better I'll like it.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: No, I'm not all right. I'm soaked and I hit myself against that rock.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I suppose that's my fault.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: All my clothes --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's right -- worry about your clothes --

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Go on, take it. Then you can't spend the rest of the trip expecting to get paid.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: There won't be any rest of the trip. Over the hill is a stage road and when we hit it you get dumped into the first stage that comes along. So keep your money. You'll need it for the fare. I'm fed up with you. I was fed up with you before we started.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: So grab yourself some sleep while you have the chance.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: If you want to go on, I can make it all right.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Like I said, I was thinkin' of the horses.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I won't have you fighting over me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Maybe it isn't going to Sonora, but it's going somewhere, which is all right with me.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It's going to Sonora.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Fine -- maybe I'll see you there sometime.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Some of 'em you didn't mean but most of 'em you did. I don't blame you because I understand your way of thinking and why you think that way. You want your women on pedestals. But they have to be born on 'em -- they can fall off but they can't climb back up.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I can't help how I think. You're trained a certain way when you're a kid and you can't change.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I can't change either. Not unless somebody wants me enough to give me a hand.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Hurry up.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I'm fool enough to believe that one of these days somebody will. Somebody who wants me as I am will maybe walk into the place where I'm working and take me out of there.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Maybe they will.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Goodbye. Thanks for the lift.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Goodbye, Mary.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: By the way, if you ever go past the Wyatt ranch, have another talk with Elaine.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Thanks for taking over.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Thanks for loading me on the stage. I know now why you did it.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Like I said, women get in the way sometimes.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: To the other side of the street.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That job you were talkin' about, did you get it yet?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Because... well, you said you wanted a man to think enough of you to walk in the place you were working and take you out of there... tonight I was sort of tied up with Steve... but tomorrow I figured on doing just that.

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: I haven't got the job yet.

turns.speaker: CLAYTON
turns.text: Drop yours. I'm gunshy.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Then don't come sneakin' around a man's camp.

turns.speaker: CLAYTON
turns.text: A fellow sees a fire go out all of a sudden, he don't take chances. My name's Clayton and I'm looking for someone.

turns.speaker: CLAYTON
turns.text: I found their surrey --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: So did I. They were in it.

turns.speaker: CLAYTON
turns.text: She's a friend -- took off this morning sort of sudden while I wasn't around.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Here's a man says he's looking for you girls.

turns.speaker: CLAYTON
turns.text: Hello, Miss Wells.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I -- lost something.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: It wouldn't happen to be this...

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: Stretch out under the seat, Miss.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Which ranch?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: I can't --

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You've got to -- don't you understand -- they want me with them and they'll fix it so I have to go --

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: No they won't.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: How does she draw?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: A little hot.

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: I don't see no sense to makin' people leave town if they don't want to leave.

turns.speaker: STEVE
turns.text: Who's Lednov?

turns.speaker: CLAY
turns.text: A man I used to know.
